leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Codes, by their very nature, are technical documents. Every word, term and punctuation mark can add to or change the meaning of a technical requirement. It is necessary to maintain a consensus on the specific meaning of each term contained in the code. Chapter 2 performs this function by stating clearly what specific terms mean for the purposes of the code.
Code development reminder: Code change proposals to sections preceded by the designation [A] or [BS] will be considered by one of the code development committees meeting during the 2022 (Group B) Code Development Cycle.

children.body: Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following words and terms shall, for the purposes of this code, have the meanings shown in this chapter.
Words used in the present tense include the future; words stated in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter; the singular number includes the plural and the plural, the singular.
Where terms are not defined in this code and are defined in the Energy Code, Fuel Gas Code, Mechanical Code or Plumbing Code, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as in those codes.

Where terms are not defined through the methods authorized by this section, such terms shall have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context implies. Words of common usage are given their plain, natural and ordinary meanings. Words that have well-defined legal meanings are given those meanings.

diagrams.title: Exterior Exit Stairway and Ramp Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior Exit Stairway: An exit component that serves to meet one or more means of egress design requirements, such as required number of exits or exit access travel distance, and is open to yards, courts or public ways.

diagrams.title: Basic Perforated Shear Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A Perforated Shear Wall (PSW) is a wall that is fully sheathed with wood structural panels (OSB or plywood) and that has openings or "perforations" for windows and doors. The ends of the walls—rather than each individual segment, as in the Segmented Shear Wall (SSW) approach—are restrained against overturning. As for the intermediate segments of the wall, they are restrained by conventional or designed framing connections, such as those at the base of the wall that transfer the shear force resisted by the wall to the construction below. The capacity of a PSW is determined as the ratio of the strength of a wall with openings to the strength of a wall of the same length without openings.

diagrams.title: Common Path of Egress Travel
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines COMMON PATH OF EGRESS TRAVEL. as that portion of exit access travel distance measured from the most remote point of each room, area or space to that point where the occupants have separate and distinct access to two exits or exit access doorways.

Common Path of Egress Travel limitations establish the maximum distance occupants may travel before optional egress route(s) must be provided. Rooms or spaces otherwise permitted to exist with one exit access route, by occupancy, use occupant load or stories, will require additional exit access when common path of egress travel exceeds values in Table 1006.2.1. Travel should be measured orthogonally and not as a direct diagonal. The path should be measured along the longest potential path around known and anticipated obstructions to travel, including partitions, tables, chairs, and other fixtures reasonably likely to occur in the space.

Most state codes refer to "Maximum Common Path of Egress Travel Distance" in Table 1006.2.1. New Jersey has amended the table to reference "Exit Access Travel Distance". Exit access travel distance (1017.3) is measured along the "natural and unobstructed path of horizontal... egress travel." This definition would suggest a case-by-case consideration of the appropriate path of travel through a room.

Where a second exit access is provided due to excessive common path of egress travel, the exit access shall be separated per 1007.1.1. Additionally, the separate exit access from a room or space shall provide access to independent exits. Two or more means of egress from a room or space that then converge to depend on a single exit are still considered a common path of egress travel, and do not meet the code intent.

diagrams.title: Means of Egress: Basic Components
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Commentary:

The building code requires that a complete means of egress consist of three distinct parts: exit access, exit, and exit discharge. Exit access provides a clear and direct path to exits. An example is a corridor system. Exits are part of the building that provide a higher level of protection than the exit access. Examples include interior exit stairways and exit passageways. Exits then lead to the exit discharge.

The exit discharge provides a path of travel to the public way or safe dispersal area. While this looks straightforward in plan view, the interpretation and implementation can pose challenges when it's considered in three dimensions. Without reviewing site grading, what was budgeted as a sidewalk turns into an expensive stair and ramp combination.

The code defines a public way as at least 10 feet wide and open to the sky, but does not offer a prescriptive definition for safe dispersal areas—leaving it to the AHJ (Authority Having Jurisdiction) to determine what is acceptable. Designers must ensure that such areas are not only at least 50 feet away (per Section 1028) but also provide sufficient space for the expected occupant load, with at least 5 square feet per person.

It is critical to coordinate with landscape and civil disciplines early, since site grading, fencing, and even planting can unintentionally block or reduce the required egress path width.

diagrams.title: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Mezzanine: An intermediate level or levels between the floor and ceiling of any story and in accordance with Section 505.

In certain circumstances, mezzanine areas may be increased from one-third of the room below to one-half or two-thirds of the room area below if all requirements of the three exceptions are met. In addition, a number of exceptions exist for allowable enclosure of mezzanines in Section 505.3.

In the 2018 codes, a new exception for dwelling units having NFPA 13 or 13R sprinkler systems was introduced that would allow a mezzanine of up to one-half of the area below.

diagrams.title: Exit Discharge: Exceptions 1 and 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Discharge, Section 1028 - Exits are required to discharge directly to the outside of the building. However, less than 50% of the required egress may be through an interior stair. If this is the case, then all of the exceptions listed in section 1028 must be in place.

diagrams.title: Gross Area Calc.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Calculating the gross floor area is essential for understanding various aspects of a building, including occupant load and fire safety requirements. In the building code, the gross floor area is determined as the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts (Building Code Section 202). For areas without surrounding walls, they are included in the gross floor area if they fall within the horizontal projection of a roof or floor above. Next, sum the results of all areas calculated for each floor together to get the total gross floor area.

diagrams.title: Smoke Partitions vs. Smoke Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
SMOKE PARTITION. A wall assembly that extends from the top of the foundation or floor below to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above or to the underside of the ceiling above where the ceiling membrane is constructed to limit the transfer of smoke.
SMOKE BARRIER. A continuous membrane, either vertical or horizontal, such as a wall, floor or ceiling assembly, that is designed and constructed to restrict the movement of smoke.

diagrams.title: Smoke: Detection Systems vs. Alarms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Smoke alarm vs. smoke detection - Smoke alarms can be either single-station or multi-station, and are self contained units. Smoke detection is part of a larger fire alarm system, and is required to be connected to a fire alarm control panel for operation.

diagrams.title: Exit Separation at Scissor Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exit Separation at Scissor Stairs: If scissor stairs (not shown here), are connected by a 1-hour fire resistance rated corridor per 1020, exit separation distance may be measured along the corridor. In order to use this measurement method, the corridor must meet the rating requirement, even if Table 1020.1 does not require a rating for the occupancy. The interconnected scissor stairs must also be fully separated per 1023.2.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers (NFPA 13): Concealed Spaces in Eaves
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines a Draftstop as a material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

Subdividing the eave into smaller compartments with draftstopping allows sprinklers to not be installed at these locations. This is allowed as these spaces are often difficult to get into and installation may not be possible or practical.

diagrams.title: Standpipe Types
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Standpipes, Types: - There are five types of standpipes - automatic dry, automatic wet, manual dry, manual wet, and semiautomatic dry. Automatic dry systems are pressurized with air, when a hose valve is opened, the air is released and the system fills with water. Automatic wet systems are filled with water at all times. Manual dry systems are not connected to a water supply, and must be supplied with water from the fire department. This is done via a fire department connection (FDC). Manual wet systems are filled with water, but require a supplemental fire department connection to meet required demand. Semiautomatic dry systems do not have water in them, but when a hose valve is opened, a remote switch opens the valve and allows water to fill the system.

diagrams.title: Fire Alarm Notification Zones
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Zones, Notification - Fire alarm system components are separated into zones, areas that activate simultaneously. Per NFPA 72, these areas, zones, are within the natural boundaries of the building, enclosed by fire or smoke barriers, or designated by separate floors.

diagrams.title: High Rise Buildings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Most building codes define a high-rise building in terms of the height. Some jurisdictions have a different threshold for high-rise definitions. However, typically it is defined as follows:

High-Rise Building: A building with an occupied floor located more than 75 feet above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access.

High-rise buildings have unique requirements. Buildings with occupied roofs may require considering the occupied roof as an occupied floor. Verify with the local building and fire authorities for such borderline situations, as missing high-rise requirements early in the process can cause significant cost increases in construction.

diagrams.title: Fire Separation Dist: Non-Parallel Conditions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Sepatation Distance: The distance measured from the building face to one of the following:
  1. The closest interior lot line.
  2. To the centerline of a street, an alley or public way.
  3. To an imaginary line between two buildings on the lot.

The distance shall be measured at right angles from the face of the wall.

diagrams.title: Exit Access, Exit and Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines exit, exit access and exit discharge as the following:

Exit Access: That portion of a means of egress system that leads from any occupied portion of a building or structure to an exit.

Exit: That portion of a means of egress system between the exit access and the exit discharge or public way. Exit components include exterior exit doors at the level of exit discharge, interior exit stairways and ramps, exit passageways, exterior exit stairways and ramps and horizontal exits.

Exit Discharge: That portion of a means of egress system between the termination of an exit and a public way.

diagrams.title: Gypsum Sheathing vs. Wallboard
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Gypsum Board: The generic name for a family of sheet products consisting of a noncombustible core primarily of gypsum with paper surfacing. Gypsum wallboard, gypsum sheathing, gypsum base for gypsum veneer plaster, exterior gypsum soffit board, predecorated gypsum board and water-resistant gypsum backing board complying with the standards listed in Tables 2506.2, 2507.2 and Chapter 35 are types of gypsum board.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Open Parking Garage: a structure or portion of a structure with openings on two or more exterior walls that is used for the parking or storage of private motor vehicles.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage vs. Open Parking Structure requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The main differences between an open parking garage and an open parking structure are that only an open parking garages have a min. clear height and are limited to construction types I, II, and IV. Both open garages and open parking structures require a lot of ventilation, in open parking structures the open wall area is based on area per linear foot while in open parking garage open wall area is based on a percent of wall area and perimeter length.

diagrams.title: Gross Leasable Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The gross leasable area of each tenant space within a mall is the total floor area designed for the exclusive use of the tenant. Tenant leasable space is measured to the center line of walls shared with other tenants or to the outside face of the enclosing wall. For a Mall the occupant load of the required means of egress is determined by the sum of the occupant load of the gross leasable area (GLA) plus the occupant load of any food courts. The occupant load for the food court is determined as usual per section 1004. The occupant load for the gross leasable area (GLA) is defined in section 402.8.2.1 as the OLF as determined by the formula OLF = 0.00007 x GLA (in sf) +25 times the GLA (in sf).

diagrams.title: Gross vs. Net Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
BUILDING CODE DEFINITION
Floor Area, Gross: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the exterior walls of the building under consideration, exclusive of vent shafts and courts, without deduction for corridors, stairways, ramps, closets, the thickness of interior walls, columns or other features. The floor area of a building, or portion thereof, not provided with surrounding exterior walls shall be the usable area under the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above. The gross floor area shall not include shafts with no openings or interior courts.

Area, Building: The area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

Floor Area, Net: The actual occupied area not including unoccupied accessory areas such as corridors, stairways, ramps, toilet rooms, mechanical rooms and closets.

The 2014 NYC Building Code further explicitly excludes wall thicknesses, columns, fixed cabinets, equipment and furred-in spaces. Other codes do not explicitly address these items in the definition of Net Floor Area.

NFPA 1 and NFPA 101 DEFINITION
Gross Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls of the building under consideration with no deduction for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, elevator and building services shafts, or other features, but excluding floor openings associated with atriums and communicating spaces.

Net Floor Area: The floor area within the inside perimeter of the outside walls, or the outside walls and fire walls of the building, or outside and/or inside walls that bound an occupancy or incidental use area requiring the occupant load to be calculated using net floor area under consideration with deductions for hallways, stairs, closets, thickness of interior walls, columns, or other features.

Both Gross and Net area is used for occupant load calculations depending the function of the space chosen in Table 1004.5. Although effectively the same, the Building Area used for allowable building area calculations found in Chapter 5 has a unique definition, "Area, Building", in Chapter 2.

Net floor areas are also used for specific items, such as minimum required areas of dwelling unit spaces, calculation of refuge areas for horizontal exits, and calculation of occupant load factors related to determining the Risk Category in Chapter 16 when gross areas would normally be required. Also, keep in mind that local zoning / planning floor area calculations, as well as height calculations may substantially differ from the building code.

diagrams.title: Stairway and Flight of Stairs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines a flight of stairs as a continuous run of rectangular treads, winders or combination thereof from one landing to another. A stairway is One or more flights of stairs, either exterior or interior, with the necessary landings and platforms connecting them, to form a continuous and uninterrupted passage from one level to another.

Stairways play an integral role in the means of egress, serving as pivotal paths for people to evacuate a building safely during emergencies.

diagrams.title: Fire Separation at Story Levels
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The fire-resistance rating of an exterior wall is determined based upon the fire separation distance of the exterior wall and the story in which the wall is located.

diagrams.title: Level of Exit Discharge
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Level of Exit Discharge: This is third point in a means of egress - exit access, exit, exit discharge - which opens to a public way (typically, exterior to the building). Buildings on a slope or having a basement or underground spaces, may have a lowest level of exit discharge and/or a highest level of exit discharge.

diagrams.title: Building Height Measurements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building Height is measured vertically from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. If podium construction or other conditions are used, the provisions of BC Section 510 would apply as applicable. The building code definition of building height is often different from those used in planning / zoning ordinances. In addition, the current definition is different than a previous version in the building code that defined building height for various types of roof structures. Under the current definition, the building height is not measured to the top of the parapet coping.

diagrams.title: Story Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Story Above Grade Plane as any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Yards and Courts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines yards and courts as:

Yard: An open space, other than a court, unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except where specifically provided by this code, on the lot on which a building is situated.

Court:An open, uncovered space, unobstructed to the sky, bounded on three or more sides by exterior building walls or other enclosing devices.

diagrams.title: Standby Power Systems
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Standby and emergency standby power systems is an alternate source of power that is utilized to run critical systems when the primary power source fails. These are typically generators with an independent fuel source (diesel, gasoline, solar). Standby power systems are required to operate critical building systems, hazardous materials operations, and ventilation systems. Emergency standby power systems are required to operate life safety and fire alarm systems.

Standby power systems must automatically transfer on a power outage within 60 seconds, whereas emergency standby power systems must transfer within 10 seconds. Both of these systems are required to provide at least 2 hours of power. These systems must be UL 2200 listed, and be installed in accordance with IFC, NFPA 110, and NFPA 111. Section 2702.2 of the building code outlines specific occupancies and systems where these are required.

diagrams.title: Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Grade Plane as a reference plane representing the average of finished ground level adjoining the building at exterior walls. Where the finished ground level slopes away from the exterior walls, the reference plane shall be established by the lowest points within the area between the building and the lot line or, where the lot line is more than 6 feet from the building, between the building and a point 6 feet from the building.

Grade plane is an imaginary horizontal reference plane that vertical measurements for a building are based on. It represents the average of the finished ground level adjoining the building at all exterior walls. On sloping sites, the grade plane will often fall between finish floor levels, and the determination on whether a story is a basement is determined by this. Special attention should be paid to portions of building where the grade slopes away from the building, due to the requirement to use a point 6 feet away from the building (or the lot line, if closer) in those conditions.

diagrams.title: Equipment Platforms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms by definition have zero occupant load and are elevated platforms that may only be used for mechanical systems equipment or industrial process equipment. Equipment platforms do not contribute to the building area, fire area, or number of stories, and are not considered a portion of the floor below. Elements providing access to the platform such as walkways, stairs, alternating tread devices and ladders may not serve as part of the building's means of egress. Equipment platforms may not be part of a mezzanine.

children.body: The actual time that a person is an occupant within a facility for the purpose of receiving care. It shall not include a facility that is open for 24 hours and is capable of providing care to someone visiting the facility during any segment of the 24 hours.
Masonry made of autoclaved aerated concrete (AAC) units, manufactured without internal reinforcement and bonded together using thin- or thick-bed mortar.
A site, building, facility or portion thereof that complies with Chapter 11.
A continuous and unobstructed way of egress travel from any accessible point in a building or facility to a public way.
A continuous, unobstructed path that complies with Chapter 11.
A space that complies with Chapter 11.
A dwelling unit or sleeping unit that complies with this code and the provisions for Accessible units in ICC A117.1.

An approved, third-party organization that is independent of the grading and inspection agencies, and the lumber mills, and that initially accredits and subsequently monitors, on a continuing basis, the competency and performance of a grading or inspection agency related to carrying out specific tasks.
An extension or increase in floor area, number of stories or height of a building or structure.
Veneer secured and supported through the adhesion of an approved bonding material applied to an approved backing. Type and spacing of fasteners shall be noted on construction documents.
See "Solar roof plane."

Construction in which the exterior load-bearing and nonload-bearing walls and partitions are of unfired clay masonry units, and floors, roofs and interior framing are wholly or partly of wood or other approved materials.
Unfired clay masonry units to which admixtures, such as emulsified asphalt, are added during the manufacturing process to limit the units' water absorption so as to increase their durability.
Unfired clay masonry units that do not meet the definition of "Adobe, stabilized."
A metal can or plastic container up to a maximum size of 33.8 fluid ounces (1000 ml), or a glass bottle up to a maximum size of 4 fluid ounces (118 ml), designed and intended to dispense an aerosol.

Aerosol cooking spray products are those aerosol products designed to deliver a vegetable oil or a solid or nonflammable liquid to reduce sticking on cooking and baking surfaces, or to be applied to food, or both. These products have a chemical heat of combustion that is greater than 8,600 Btu/lb (20 kJ/g) and contain not more than 18 percent by weight of flammable propellant.

A combination of a container, a propellant and a material that is dispensed. Aerosol products shall be classified by means of the calculation of their chemical heats of combustion and shall be designated Level 1, Level 2 or Level 3.
Those with a total chemical heat of combustion that is less than or equal to 8,600 British thermal units per pound (Btu/lb) (20 kJ/g).
Those with a total chemical heat of combustion that is greater than 8,600 Btu/lb (20 kJ/g), but less than or equal to 13,000 Btu/lb (30 kJ/g).
Those with a total chemical heat of combustion that is greater than 13,000 Btu/lb (30 kJ/g).
A building used for warehousing aerosol products.

See ORS 447.210(1)
ORS 447.210(1) is not a part of this code but is reprinted here for the reader's convenience:

447.210 Definitions.
  1. "Affected buildings" includes any place of public accommodations and commercial facilities designed, constructed and altered in compliance with the accessibility standards established by the Americans with Disabilities Act. "Affected buildings" also includes any government building that is subject to Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. "Affected buildings" also includes private entities, private membership clubs and churches that have more than one floor level and more than 4,000 square feet in ground area or that are more than 20 feet in height, measured from the top surface of the lowest flooring to the highest interior overhead finish of the building. [1971 c.230 §2; 1973 c.539 §1; 1975 c.675 §35; 1979 c.133 §1; 1987 c.414 §27; 1987 c.604 §12; 1989 c.224 §109; 1991 c.67 §122; 1993 c.503 §1; 1993 c.744 §74; 1995 c.307 §1; 2011 c.488 §1]
In roofing, crushed stone, crushed slag or water-worn gravel used for surfacing for roof coverings.
See ORS 455.315 and Appendix C.
A facility, or portion thereof, housing operations involving the transforming of raw agricultural products into intermediate or consumable products.
A structure that uses air-pressurized membrane beams, arches or other elements to enclose space. Occupants of such a structure do not occupy the pressurized area used to support the structure.
A structure wherein the shape of the structure is attained by air pressure and occupants of the structure are within the elevated pressure area. Air-supported structures are of two basic types:
Similar to a single skin, but with an attached liner that is separated from the outer skin and provides an airspace which serves for insulation, acoustic, aesthetic or similar purposes.
Where there is only the single outer skin and the air pressure is directly against that skin.
An unenclosed exit access component that defines and provides a path of egress travel.
That portion of an exit access that leads to an aisle.
See "Nuisance alarm."
See "Multiple-station alarm device."
A fire alarm system component such as a bell, horn, speaker, light or text display that provides audible, tactile or visible outputs, or any combination thereof.
A signal indicating an emergency requiring immediate action, such as a signal indicative of fire.

A feature of automatic fire detection and alarm systems to reduce unwanted alarms wherein smoke detectors report alarm conditions for a minimum period of time, or confirm alarm conditions within a given time period, after being automatically reset, in order to be accepted as a valid alarm-initiation signal.

A method of proportioning structural members, such that elastically computed stresses produced in the members by nominal loads do not exceed specified allowable stresses (also called "working stress design").
Any construction or renovation to an existing structure other than repair or addition.

A device that has a series of steps between 50 and 70 degrees (0.87 and 1.22 rad) from horizontal, usually attached to a center support rail in an alternating manner so that the user does not have both feet on the same level at the same time.

Buildings or portions thereof used to provide medical, surgical, psychiatric, nursing or similar care on a less than 24-hour basis to persons who are rendered incapable of self-preservation by the services provided or staff has accepted responsibility for care recipients already incapable.
Metal rod, wire or strap that secures masonry to its structural support.
An exterior perimeter building of a group other than H having direct access to a covered or open mall building but having required means of egress independent of the mall.
Veneer secured with approved mechanical fasteners to an approved backing.
The opening around the penetrating item.
A unit containing one or more indicator lamps, alphanumeric displays or other equivalent means in which each indication provides status information about a circuit, condition or location.
Acceptable to the building official.

An established and recognized agency that is regularly engaged in conducting tests, furnishing inspection services or furnishing product certification where such agency has been approved by the building official.
An established and qualified person, firm or corporation approved by the building official pursuant to Chapter 17 of this code.
An organization primarily established for purposes of testing to approved standards and approved by the local municipality.
An independent person, firm or corporation, approved by the building official, who is competent and experienced in the application of engineering principles to materials, methods or systems analyses.
The area delineated by the out-to-out specified dimensions of masonry in the plane under consideration.
The area of masonry units, grout and mortar crossed by the plane under consideration based on out-to-out specified dimensions.

The area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

diagrams.title: Building Area (Definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the building code, the building area is the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

diagrams.title: Gross Area Calc.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Calculating the gross floor area is essential for understanding various aspects of a building, including occupant load and fire safety requirements. In the building code, the gross floor area is determined as the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts (Building Code Section 202). For areas without surrounding walls, they are included in the gross floor area if they fall within the horizontal projection of a roof or floor above. Next, sum the results of all areas calculated for each floor together to get the total gross floor area.

diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms by definition have zero occupant load and are elevated platforms that may only be used for mechanical systems equipment or industrial process equipment. Equipment platforms do not contribute to the building area, fire area, or number of stories, and are not considered a portion of the floor below. Elements providing access to the platform such as walkways, stairs, alternating tread devices and ladders may not serve as part of the building's means of egress. Equipment platforms may not be part of a mezzanine.

children.body: See "Solar roof plane."
An area where persons unable to use stairways can remain temporarily to await instructions or assistance during emergency evacuation.
That portion of an indoor or outdoor space on the site of an affected building where the play or practice of a sport occurs.
A subsurface space adjacent to a building open at the top or protected at the top by a grating or guard.
See "Photovoltaic array."
A storage configuration having a 6-inch (152 mm) or smaller width vertical flue space that restricts air movement through the stored commodity.
The configuration of storage. Characteristics considered in defining an array include the type of packaging, flue spaces, height of storage and compactness of storage.
See "Multilevel assembly seating."
A vertical space that is closed at the top, connecting two or more stories in Group I-2 and I-3 occupancies or three or more stories in all other occupancies.

Enclosure of Atriums: Exception 2 - Glass Block Partition
